  physical_appearance: The image shows a photograph in black-and-white that is enclosed by a white frame. A river can be seen from the bottom left right hand corner to the left side of the photograph. On the left hand side of the river
 grasses grow on the ground. To the right of the river
 there are several villages which look to be in dilapidated conditions. The villages are all clustered and there are palm trees growing alongside them.

  subject_terms_1: villages landscapes (representations) river settlements multiple dwellings

  subject_terms_2: Villages Dwellings Landscapes Singapore Black-and-white photography

  subject_terms_3: Photography Sungei Whampoa

  sgcool_label_text: Loke Hong Seng (b. 1943) was working as a radio announcer with Radio Television Singapore in the 1960s when he picked up photography and subsequently grew to specialize in street photography. His images of 1960s and 1970s Singapore offer a candid view of everyday life in the early days of the nation’s development. This photograph captures the attap houses along Whampoa River
 soon to be demolished in a time of resettlement and redevelopment.

metadata.physical_appearance: The image shows a photograph in black-and-white that is enclosed by a white frame. A river can be seen from the bottom left right hand corner to the left side of the photograph. On the left hand side of the river, grasses grow on the ground. To the right of the river, there are several villages which look to be in dilapidated conditions. The villages are all clustered and there are palm trees growing alongside them.

metadata.sgcool_label_text: Loke Hong Seng (b. 1943) was working as a radio announcer with Radio Television Singapore in the 1960s when he picked up photography and subsequently grew to specialize in street photography. His images of 1960s and 1970s Singapore offer a candid view of everyday life in the early days of the nation’s development. This photograph captures the attap houses along Whampoa River, soon to be demolished in a time of resettlement and redevelopment.
